ygData.subject: Re: Into the Teeth! (Tuscon)
ygData.msgSnippet: Tucson needed to avoid falling into the same trap that Magmatron fell into.  He had been warned before about his temper and now was the true test of control.

Tucson needed to avoid falling into the same trap that Magmatron fell into.=
  He had been warned before about his temper and now was the true test of c=
ontrol.  He shakes his head to try and knock some sense into himself, which=
 he was finding very hard to do.  

" You're right Big Convoy, I shouldn't =
be as aggressive as I am, I'm just extremely frustrated by the fact that I =
can't pull Rodimus out of corruption as I hoped to the first time I rescued=
 him.  What I really need is guidance, not violence.  But in order to attem=
pt another recovery, I will have to fight him. I must knock whatever it is =
that's controlling him out of his internal programming.  By some form of st=
rong impact, I may be able to jostle something loose to enable Rodimus to r=
egain control of his own logic circuitry.     Then I have to get him to sur=
render the matrix for safe keeping until such time Rodimus is free of his i=
nvasive programming..  Thank you for stopping me by the way, I'm glad you w=
ere honest with me."

Perpetually on the move and constantly busy. 

On Oct=
 13, 2011, at 9:23 AM, Super Cyclonus <supercyclonus@...> wrote:

> T=
here was a watchful look from BIG CONVOY as he listened to TUSCON,
> and al=
though it could not be seen in the darkness a frown was growing
> across hi=
s face.
> 
> "I hear you." He said finally as TUSCON came to an end. "But y=
ou are
> heading down a dangerous road."
> 
> CONVOY sat down on a stool an=
d looked over at one of the gratings in
> the wall and then back at TUSCON,=
 "Once Magamatron talked much as you
> do now. The anger, the desire for ve=
ngance. Back when he was one of
> the early Maximals."
> 
> (TAG)
> 
> Pres=
ton
> 
> On 10/12/11, Sandy Panico <magicquartz@...> wrote:
> > Tucso=
n nods in understanding. He wasn't going blind after all but the lack
> > o=
f light did not bother him in the least. He settles down with Big Convoy,
>=
 > coiling his long tail as a courtesy to his new comrade, hoping not to im=
pose
> > on him at all. As he lays down, he tucks all four limbs under his =
body and
> > gives a bit of a yawn. His teeth and saber like fangs glisten =
in what
> > little light there could be in the chamber. After a long stretc=
h of his
> > jaws, Tucson closes his mouth and turns to Big Convoy.
> >
> >=
 " So much corruption, greed and deception. How much of that can any planet=

> > endure before it comes to it's death? Magmatron is to me a murderer fr=
om
> > what you told me. I do hope our alliance can finally put an end to h=
is
> > unjust wrath. And one thing is certain, and I hate to admit it, but =
after
> > seeing what has been done to Rodimus and his own lack of determin=
ation to
> > fend off his own demons, there isn't anything I can do to help=
 him. I tried
> > and I almost succeeded but a lot of that depends on Rodim=
us. If he wants to
> > fight it he has to do that on his own. But I know no=
w that he chose his
> > path, and I can not get him out of his own mess. An=
d a bit of a mess it is.
> > He wants to work as an enemy, then so be it. H=
e will be treated as one.
> > Big Convoy, you will see a part of me that ma=
y appear rather ruthless, but
> > it is only to convey an important message=
. Those who oppose me pay a
> > painful price, and Rodimus has now opposed =
me more than a few times. He
> > will not be spared of his consequences whe=
n we encounter each other. To me
> > he is THE ENEMY."
> >
> > His optics g=
low an icy blue as draconic eyes narrow in thought.
> 

--Apple-Mail-10-903932590

<html><body bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF"><div>Tucson needed to avoid falling into th=
e same trap that Magmatron fell into.  He had been warned before about=
 his temper and now was the true test of control.  He shakes his head =
to try and knock some sense into himself, which he was finding very hard to=
 do.  </div><div><br></div><div>" You're right Big Convoy, I shouldn't=
 be as aggressive as I am, I'm just extremely frustrated by the fact that I=
 can't pull Rodimus out of corruption as I hoped to the first time I rescue=
d him.  What I really need is guidance, not violence.  But in ord=
er to attempt another recovery, I will have to fight him. I must knock what=
ever it is that's controlling him out of his internal programming.  By=
 some form of strong impact, I may be able to jostle something loose to ena=
ble Rodimus to regain control of his own logic circuitry.     The=
n I have to get him to surrender the matrix for safe keeping until such tim=
e Rodimus is free of his invasive programming..  Thank you for stoppin=
g me by the way, I'm glad you were honest with me."</div><div><br>Perpetual=
ly on the move and constantly busy. </div><div><br>On Oct 13, 2011, at=
 9:23 AM, Super Cyclonus <<a href=3D"mailto:supercyclonus@...">sup=
ercyclonus@...</a>> wrote:<br><br></div><div></div><blockquote typ=
e=3D"cite"><div>




<span style=3D"display:none"> </span>



    <div=
 id=3D"ygrp-text">
      
      
      <p>There was a watchful look from BI=
G CONVOY as he listened to TUSCON,<br>
and although it could not be seen in=
 the darkness a frown was growing<br>
across his face.<br>
<br>
"I hear you=
." He said finally as TUSCON came to an end. "But you are<br>
heading down =
a dangerous road."<br>
<br>
CONVOY sat down on a stool and looked over at o=
ne of the gratings in<br>
the wall and then back at TUSCON, "Once Magamatro=
n talked much as you<br>
do now. The anger, the desire for vengance. Back w=
hen he was one of<br>
the early Maximals."<br>
<br>
(TAG)<br>
<br>
Preston<=
br>
<br>

a>> wrote:<br>

 after all but the lack<br>
> of light did not bother him in the least. =
 He settles down with Big Convoy,<br>
> coiling his long tail as a court=
esy to his new comrade, hoping not to impose<br>
> on him at all.  As he=
 lays down, he tucks all four limbs under his body and<br>
> gives a bit=
 of a yawn.  His teeth and saber like fangs glisten in what<br>
> little=
 light there could be  in the chamber.  After a long stretch of his<br>
&gt=
; jaws, Tucson closes his mouth and turns to Big Convoy.<br>
><br>
> =
" So much corruption, greed and deception.  How much of that can any planet=
<br>
> endure before it comes to it's death? Magmatron is to me a murder=
er from<br>
> what you told me.  I do hope our alliance can finally put =
an end to his<br>
> unjust wrath.  And one thing is certain, and I hate =
to admit it, but after<br>
> seeing what has been done to Rodimus and hi=
s own lack of determination to<br>
> fend off his own demons, there isn'=
t anything I can do to help him.  I tried<br>
> and I almost succeeded b=
ut a lot of that depends on Rodimus.  If he wants to<br>
> fight it he h=
as to do that on his own.  But I know now that he chose his<br>
> path, =
and I can not get him out of his own mess.  And a bit of a mess it is.<br>
=
>  He wants to work as an enemy, then so be it.  He will be treated as o=
ne.<br>
> Big Convoy, you will see a part of me that may appear rather r=
uthless, but<br>
> it is only to convey an important message.  Those who=
 oppose me pay a<br>
> painful price, and Rodimus has now opposed me mor=
e than a few times.  He<br>
> will not be spared of his consequences whe=
n we encounter each other.  To me<br>
> he is THE ENEMY."<br>
><br>
&=
gt; His optics glow an icy blue as draconic eyes narrow in thought.<br>
</p=
